{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3486521,"name":"Adam","username":"spontarelliam","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-18T12:38:07.076Z","cooked":"

I wanted to post an update to the RoboRio on Linux tutorial found here. Marshall’s guide was very helpful in figuring this out, but it didn’t quite work in our lab that runs Debian 12.

Debian 12, along with other distros, has moved away from /etc/network/interfaces and now uses NetworkManager on the desktop (link). So the first deviation from Marshall’s guide is that you do not use /etc/dhcpcd.conf to set a static ip, instead you create a new network configuration file at:

/etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/roborio.nmconnection

[connection]
  id=roboRIO
  type=ethernet
  interface-name=usb0
[ethernet]
[ipv4]
  address1=172.22.11.1/24,172.22.11.1
  method=manual
[ipv6]
  addr-gen-mode=stable-privacy
  method=auto
[proxy]

Next, setup isc-dhcp-server just as described previously.

Finally, the udev rule changes is a bit. udev isn’t needed to assign a static IP to the interface, as this is the job for NetworkManager. It’s only needed to start and stop isc-dhcp-server when the roborio is plugged and unplugged.

create /etc/udev/rules.d/98-rio.rules as follows:

SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", ENV{ID_BUS}=="usb", ENV{ID_VENDOR_ID}=="3923", RUN="ip a", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="isc-dhcp-server.service"
ACTION=="remove", ENV{ID_BUS}=="usb", ENV{ID_MODEL}=="NI_roboRIO*", RUN="/usr/bin/systemctl stop isc-dhcp-server.service"

Apply these changes as before,

udevadm control --reload
systemctl daemon-reload

Then plug in your roboRIO and confirm that an interface named usb0 is created with an ip of 172.22.11.1 on your desktop.

ip a

Then test that communications are working by pinging the roboRIO.

ping 172.22.11.2

Hopefully this helps others. If you have any questions, let me know!
